title: Syllabus
text:
Term: Spring 2025
Instructor: Isaac Quintanilla Salinas
Email: isaac.qs@csuci.edu
Office Location: BTE 2840
Office Hours:

Mon/Wed 4-5 PM
Tues 10 AM - 12 PM

Or by Zoom appointment.
Lecture:

Sec 01: MW 12-1:15 PM (BT 1642)
Sec 02: MW 1:30-3 PM (BT 1642)




Critical reasoning using a quantitative and statistical, problem-solving approach to solving real-world problems. Topics include: probability and statistics, sample data, probability and empirical data distributions, sampling techniques, estimation and hypothesis testing, ANOVA, and correlation and regression analysis. Students will use standard statistical software to analyze real-world and simulated data. GenEd: B4




Prepare students for advanced courses in data-management and statistics
Reason both inductively and deductively with quantitative information and data
Use statistical software for complex statistical analysis of real-world and simulated data
Empower students to apply computational and inferential thinking to address real-world problems
Write the results of a statistical study and draw conclusion in reports




Introduction to Modern Statistics (IMS)
Statistical Modeling (SM)

Participation is based on short writing assignments conducted in class. There will be no make ups for these writing prompts.



Notebook assignments are designed to expand your statistical knowledge. These will be completed in Google Colab which can be accessed from Canvas. There is one notebook assignments every week that you can be completed during class time. Notebook assignments will be due on Wednesday at 11:59 PM every week.



Reading assignments are designed to teach you different statistical concepts. As the course progresses, many of the concepts build on each other. Therefore, the assignments encourage you to read each chapter in an appropriate amount of time. You must read the chapter and answer the questions by the Friday night at 11:59 PM. The 3 lowest reading assignments will be dropped.



Videos are used to teach statistical concepts related to the course. Students are expected to watch at least one video a week. The videos are implemented using VoiceThreads. The 3 lowest video assignments will be dropped. Video assignments will be due every Sunday at 11:59 PM.



Homework assignmets are designed to give you an opportunity to practice what is viewed from the video assignments. The assignments will require you to program in R. The 3 lowest homework assignments will be dropped. Homework assignments will be due every Sunday at 11:59 PM.



There will be three in exams. Exam #1 will be on March 3, Exam #2 will be on April 7, and Exam #3 will be on May 12 at 10:30 AM to 12:30 PM (Sec 01) or May 14 1-3 PM (Sec 02). While the exams are not considered cumulative, the material builds on each other. Developing a strong understanding of the material through out the course is important for your success. At the end of the semester, your lowest exam grade will be replaced by your median average exam grade. This course will operate under a zero-tolerance policy. Talking during the time of the exam, sharing materials, looking at another students’ exam, or not following directions given will be subject to the University’s academic integrity policy.



There will be 4 extra credit opportunities worth a total of 10% of your overall grade. (There are no make-ups for missed extra credit assignments!) More information will be provided on the extra credit assignments on a later date. Information on the extra credit can be found here.

Academic Honesty:
Conduct yourself with honesty and integrity. Do not submit others’ work as your own. For assignments and quizzes that allow you to work with a group, only put your name on what the group submits if you genuinely contributed to the work. Work completely independently on exams, using only the materials that are indicated as allowed. Failure to observe academic honesty results in substantial penalties that can include failing the course.
Disabilities:
If you are a student with a disability requesting reasonable accommodations in this course, you need to contact Disability Accommodations and Support Services (DASS) located on the second floor of Arroyo Hall, via email accommodations@csuci.edu or call 805-437-3331. All requests for reasonable accommodations require registration with DASS in advance of need: https://www.csuci.edu/dass/students/apply-for-services.htm. Faculty, students and DASS will work together regarding classroom accommodations. You are encouraged to discuss approved.

Students are expected to adhere to all health and safety requirements as noted on the University’s Spring 2023 Semester website or they may be subject to removal from the classroom.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Melanoma
Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that causes the cells that produce melanin to grow out of control. What makes Melanoma so dangerous is that it can metastasize to other parts of the body.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Outcome of Interest
We are interested in learning how do different factors affect and individual’s chances of survival. Therefore, we are measuring patients and if they lived or died during a study period.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Data
We will be using the Melanoma data set with the following variables: dead (died by Melanoma, 1=yes, 0= no), sex (1 = male, 0 = female), age (in years), thickness (tumour thickness in mm), ulcer (1 = presence, 0 absent).

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Plot


Code
Melanoma |> 
  ggplot(aes(thickness, dead)) +
  geom_point()

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Construct Model
\[
\left(\begin{array}{c}
Dead \\
Alive
\end{array}\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1X
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Let …
\[
Y = \left\{\begin{array}{cc}
1 & Dead \\
0 & Alive
\end{array}\right.
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Construct a Model
\[
P\left(Y = 1\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1X
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Construct a Model
\[
P\left(Y = 1\right) = \frac{e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}{1 + e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Construct a Model
\[
\frac{P(Y = 1)}{P(Y = 0)} = e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}
\]
where \(\frac{P(Y = 1)}{P(Y = 0)}\) are considered the odds of observing \(Y = 1\).

title: Logistic Regression
text:
The Logistic Model
\[
\log\left\{\frac{P(Y = 1)}{P(Y = 0)}\right\} = \beta_0 + \beta_1X
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Logistic Regression
Logistic Regression is used to model the association between a set of predictors and a binary outcome variable.

This is similar Linear Regression which models the association between a set of predictors and a numerical outcome variable.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Logistic Regression
Logistic Regression uses the logistic model to formulate the relationship between the predictors and the outcome.

More specifically, for an outcome of Y:
\[
Y = \left\{\begin{array}{cc}
1 & \text{Category 1} \\
0 & \text{Category 2}
\end{array}\right.
\]
The Predictors variable will model the probability of observing category 1 (\(P(Y=1)\))

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Logistic Model
\[
\log\left\{\frac{P(Y = 1)}{P(Y = 0)}\right\} = \beta_0 + \beta_1X
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Regression Coefficients \(\beta\)
The regression coefficients quantify how a specific predictor changes the odds of observing the first category of the outcome (\(Y = 1\))

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Estimating \(\beta\)
To obtain the numerical value for \(\beta\), denoted as \(\hat \beta\), we will be finding the values of \(\hat \beta\) that maximizes the likelihood function:
\[
L(\boldsymbol \beta) = \prod_{i=1}^n \left(\frac{e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}{1 + e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}\right)^{Y_i}\left(\frac{1}{1 + e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}\right)^{1-Y_i}
\]
The likelihood function can be thought as the probability of observing the entire data set. Therefore, we want to choose the values the \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) that will result in the highest probability of observing the data.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Estimated Parameters
The values you obtain (\(\hat \beta\)) tell you the relationship between the a predictor variable and the log odds of observing the first category of the outcome \(Y=1\).

Exponentiating the estimate (\(e^{\hat \beta}\)) will give you the relationship between a predictor variable and the odds of observing the first category of the outcome \(Y=1\).

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Interpreting \(\hat \beta\)
For a continuous predictor variable:
As X increases by 1 unit, the odds of observing the first category (\(Y = 1\)) increases by a factor of \(e^{\hat\beta}\).
For a categorical predictor variable (first dummy variable):
The odds of observing the first category (\(Y = 1\)) in the indicated category (\(D=1\)) is \(e^{\hat\beta}\) times higher/lower compared to the reference category (\(D=0\)).

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Logistic Regression in R


Code
glm(Y ~ X1 + X2 + ... + Xp,
    data = DATA,
    family = binomial())

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example
Modelling dead by sex, age, thickness, and ulcer:


Code
glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())


#> 
#> Call:  glm(formula = dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer, family = binomial(), 
#>     data = Melanoma)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#> (Intercept)          sex          age    thickness        ulcer  
#>    -2.39860      0.40767      0.00402      0.11253      1.31314  
#> 
#> Degrees of Freedom: 204 Total (i.e. Null);  200 Residual
#> Null Deviance:       242.4 
#> Residual Deviance: 210.3     AIC: 220.3


\[
\log(odds) = -2.40 + 0.41 M + 0.004 age + 0.11 thick + 1.31ulc
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Interpretation
\[
\log(odds) = -2.40 + 0.41 M + 0.004 age + 0.11 thick + 1.31ulc
\]

The odds of experiencing death in males is 1.5 times larger than the odds for females, adjusting for age, tumor thickness and the presence of an ulcer.


As age increases by 1 year, the odds of experiencing death increases by a factor of 1.004, adjusting for sex, tumor thickness and presence of an ulcer.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Working with probabilities
As you can see, working with odds may be unintuitive for the average person. It will be better to predict the probability and display those results to individuals.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Predicting Probability
\[
\hat P\left(Y = 1\right) = \frac{e^{\hat\beta_0 + \hat\beta_1X_1 + \cdots  + \hat \beta_pX_p}}{1 + e^{\hat\beta_0 + \hat\beta_1X_1 + \cdots  + \hat \beta_pX_p}}
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Prediction in R


Code
xglm <- glm(Y ~ X1 + X2 + ... + Xp,
            data = DATA,
            family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(X1 = VAL,  X2 = VAL, ..., Xp = VAL)
predict(xglm,
        predict_df,
        type = "response")

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example 1
Predict the probability of observing death for a patient who is male, 75 years old, an tumor thickness of 2.9, and with ulcer presence.


Code
xglm <- glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(sex = 1, age = 75, thickness = 2.9, ulcer = 1)
predict(xglm, predict_df, type = "response")


#>         1 
#> 0.4875223

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example 1
Predict the probability of observing death for a patient who is male, 75 years old, an tumor thickness of 2.9, and without ulcer presence.


Code
xglm <- glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(sex = 1, age = 75, thickness = 2.9, ulcer = 0)
predict(xglm, predict_df, type = "response")


#>         1 
#> 0.2037438

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example 1




Ulcer Present
Ulcer not Present




Probabiltiy
48.7%
20.3%



For a patient who is 75 years old, male, and a tumor thickness of 2.9, when an ulcer is present, the probability a patient dies increases to 48% compared to a patient who does not have an ulcer with a probability of 20%.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example 2
Predict the probability of observing death for a patient who is female, 75 years old, an tumor thickness of 2.9, and with ulcer presence.


Code
xglm <- glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(sex = 0, age = 75, thickness = 2.9, ulcer = 1)
predict(xglm, predict_df, type = "response")


#>         1 
#> 0.3875575

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example 2
Predict the probability of observing death for a patient who is female, 55 years old, an tumor thickness of 2.9, and with ulcer presence.


Code
xglm <- glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(sex = 0, age = 55, thickness = 2.9, ulcer = 1)
predict(xglm, predict_df, type = "response")


#>         1 
#> 0.3686531

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example 2




55
75




Probabiltiy
36.8%
38.7%



For a patient who is female, a tumor thickness of 2.9, and has an ulcer, the probability a 75 year old patient dies increases to 38.7% compared to a 55 year old patient with a probability of 36.8%.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Explaining Variation

This is the process where we try to reduce the variation with the use of other variables.


Can be thought of as getting it less wrong when taking an educated guess.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text: Explaining Variation

title: Simple Linear Regression
text: Explaining Variation with One Variable

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Generated Model
\[
Y \sim DGP_1
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text: A Simple Model

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
A Simple Model
\[
Y = \_\_\_ + error
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Notation
\[
Y = \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ + \varepsilon
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
The Simple Generated Model
\[
Y \sim \mu + \varepsilon
\]
\[
\varepsilon \sim DGP_2
\]

\(DGP_2\) is not the same as the \(DGP_1\), it is transformed due \(\beta_0\). Consider this the NULL \(DGP\).

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Observing Data
\[
Y = \beta_0 + \varepsilon
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Estimated Line
\[
\hat Y=\hat\beta_0
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Notation


Observed
\[
Y = \beta_0 + \varepsilon
\]

Estimated
\[
\hat Y = \hat \beta_0
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Indexing Data
The data in a data set can be indexed by a number.

penguins[1,-c(1:2)]

#> # A tibble: 1 × 6
#>   bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g sex    year
#>            <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int> <fct> <int>
#> 1           39.1          18.7               181        3750 male   2007



Making the variable “body_mass_g” be represented by \(Y\) and “flipper_length_mm” as \(X\):
\[
Y_1 = 3750 \ \ X_1=181
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Indexing Data
\[
Y_i, X_i
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Data
With the data that we collect from a sample, we hypothesize how the data was generated.

Using a simple model:
\[
Y_i = \beta_0 + \varepsilon_i
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Estimated Value
\[
\hat Y_i = \hat \beta_0
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Estimation
To estimate \(\hat \beta_0\), we minimize the follow function:
\[
\sum^n_{i=1} (Y_i-\hat Y_i)^2
\]

This is known as the sum squared errors, SSE

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Residuals
The residuals are known as the observed errors from the data in the model:
\[
r_i = Y_i - \hat Y_i
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Estimation in R

lm(Y ~ 1, data = DATA)

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Modeling Body Mass in Penguins

lm(body_mass_g ~ 1, data = penguins)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = body_mass_g ~ 1, data = penguins)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#> (Intercept)  
#>        4207

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Linear Model
The goal of Statistics is to develop models the have a better explanation of the outcome \(Y\).

In particularly, reduce the sum of squared errors.


By utilizing a bit more of information, \(X\), we can increase the predicting capabilities of the model.


Thus, the linear model is born.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Linear Model
\[
Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X + \varepsilon
\]
\[
\varepsilon \sim DGP_3
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Scatter Plot


Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + 
  geom_point() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(size = 24),
                   axis.title.x = element_text(size = 30),
                   plot.title = element_text(size = 48),
                   strip.text = element_text(size = 20),
                   legend.title = element_blank(),
                   legend.text = element_text(size = 24))

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Imposing a Line


Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + 
  geom_point() +
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = F) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(size = 24),
                   axis.title.x = element_text(size = 30),
                   plot.title = element_text(size = 48),
                   strip.text = element_text(size = 20),
                   legend.title = element_blank(),
                   legend.text = element_text(size = 24))

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Modelling the Data
\[
Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_i + \varepsilon_i
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Linear Model
\[
\hat Y_i = \hat \beta_0 + \hat \beta_1 X_i
\]

Goal is to obtain numerical values for \(\hat \beta_0\) and \(\hat \beta_1\) that will minimize the SSE.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
SSE
\[
\sum^n_{i=1} (Y_i-\hat Y_i)^2
\]
\[
\hat Y_i = \hat \beta_0 + \hat \beta_1 X_i
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Fitting a Model in R

lm(Y ~ X, data = DATA)

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Example
Y: “body_mass_g”; X: “flipper_length_mm”

lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm, data = penguins)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm, data = penguins)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>       (Intercept)  flipper_length_mm  
#>          -5872.09              50.15


\[
\hat Y_i = -5872.09 + 50.15 X_i
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Interpretation of \(\hat\beta_0\)
The intercept \(\hat \beta_0\) can be interpreted as the base value when \(X\) is set to 0.

Some times the intercept can be interpretable to real world scenarios.


Other times it cannot.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Interpreting Example
\[
\hat Y_i = -5872.09 + 50.15 X_i
\] When flipper length is 0 mm, the body mass is -5872 grams.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Interpretation of \(\hat \beta_1\)
The slope \(\hat \beta_1\) indicates how will y change when x increases by 1 unit.

It will demonstrate if there is, on average, a positive or negative relationship based on the sign provided.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Interpreting Example
\[
\hat Y_i = -5872.09 + 50.15 X_i
\]
When flipper length increases by 1 mm, the body mass will increase by 50.15 grams.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Linear Models with Categorical Variables
A line is normally used to model 2 continuous variables.

However, the predictor variable \(X\) can be restricted to a set a variables that can symbolize categories.


A category will be used as a reference for a model.

title: Simple Linear Regression
Simple Linear Regression
text:
Binary (Dummy) Variables
To fit a model with categorical variables, we must utilize dummy (binary) variables that indicate which category is being referenced. We use \(C-1\) dummy variables where \(C\) indicates the number of categories. When coded correctly, each category will be represented by a combination of dummy variables.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Linear Model
\[
\hat Y_i = \hat \beta_0 + \hat\beta_1 D_{1i} + \hat\beta_2 D_{2i}
\]

\(\hat \beta_1\) indicates how body mass changes from Adelie to Chinstrap.


\(\hat \beta_2\) indicates how body mass changes from Adelie to Gentoo.


\(\hat \beta_0\) represents the baseline level, in this case the body mass of Adelie.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Fitting a Model in R

lm(Y ~ X, data = DATA)

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Example

lm(body_mass_g ~ species, penguins)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = body_mass_g ~ species, data = penguins)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>      (Intercept)  speciesChinstrap     speciesGentoo  
#>          3706.16             26.92           1386.27


\[
\hat Y_i = 3706 + 26.92 D_{1i} + 1386.27 D_{2i}
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Finding the Adelie MASS
\[
\hat Y_i = 3706 + 26.92 (0) + 1386.27 (0)
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Finding the Chinstrap MASS
\[
\hat Y_i = 3706 + 26.92 (1) + 1386.27 (0)
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Finding the Gentoo MASS
\[
\hat Y_i = 3706 + 26.92 (0) + 1386.27 (1)
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Intepreting \(\hat \beta_1\)
On average, Chinstrap has a larger mass than Adelie by about 26.92 grams.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Intepreting \(\hat \beta_2\)
On average, Gentoo has a larger mass than Adelie by about 1386.27 grams.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Correlation
Correlation is a statistics that can be used to describe the strength of the relationship between 2 continuous variables.

\[
r = \frac{1}{n-1}\sum^n_{i=1}\frac{x_i - \bar x}{s_x}\frac{y_i - \bar y}{s_y}
\]

\(\bar x\), \(\bar y\): sample means
\(s_x\), \(s_y\): sample standard deviations



\[
-1 \leq r \leq 1
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Correlations

From IMS 2e

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Coefficient of Determination
The coefficient of determination evaluates the strength between an outcome \(Y\) and the linear model, which includes \(X\).

\[
R^2 = r^2
\]


\[
0 \leq R^2 \leq 1
\]


The coefficient of determination measures the total variation explained by the linear model. The closer to 1, the better the linear model.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Correlation in R

cor(DATA$Y, DATA$X)

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Example

cor(penguins$body_mass_g, penguins$flipper_length_mm)

#> [1] 0.8729789

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Coefficient of Determination in R

xlm <- lm(Y ~ X, data = DATA)
r2(xlm)

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Example

xlm <- lm(body_mass_g ~ species, penguins)
r2(xlm)

#> [1] 0.6744887

title: Numerical Data
text: Motivating Example

title: Numerical Data
text:
Summary Statistics
Summary statistics are used to describe the distribution of data.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Central Tendency
Central tendency is a statistical concept that refers to the central or typical value around which a set of data points tends to cluster. It is used to summarize and describe a data set by identifying a single representative value that provides insights into the data’s overall characteristics.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Variation
Variation in statistics refers to the extent to which data points in a dataset deviate or differ from a central tendency measure. Understanding variation is crucial for making informed decisions, drawing meaningful conclusions, and assessing the reliability of statistical analyses.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Minimum
The minimum (min) is the smallest value in the data.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Maximum
The maximum (max) is the largest value in the data.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Quartiles
Quartiles are three values (Q1, Q2, Q3) that divides the data into four subsets.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Q1
Q1 is the value signifying that a quarter of the data is lower than it.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Q2 - Median
Q2 is the value signifying that half of the data is below it.

The median also represents the central tendency of the data.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Q3
Q3 is the value signifying that 3 quarters of the data is below it.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Interquartile Range

\[
IQR = Q_3 - Q_1
\]

title: Numerical Data
text:
Range

\[
R = \mathrm{max} - \mathrm{min}
\]

title: Numerical Data
text:
How to identify the quartiles?

Sort the data
ID Max and Min
Find the amount of data the makes a quarter:

\(K=N/4\)

Create 4 groups using the sorted data

group by data size
If \(K\) has a decimal, the \(Kth\) value is quartile of each group.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Mean
Describe how you will find the mean of these numbers:


#> [1] 15 14 17  9 14

title: Numerical Data
text:
Mean
The mean is another measurement for central tendency.
\[
\bar X = \frac{1}{n}\sum^n_{i=1}X_i
\]

\(n\): total data points
\(X_i\): data points
\(i\): indexing data
\(\sum\): add all from first (bottom) to last (up)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Variance
The variance is a measurement on the average squared distance the data points are from the central tendency.
\[
s^2 = \frac{1}{n-1}\sum^n_{i=1}(X_i-\bar X)^2
\]

title: Numerical Data
text:
Standard Deviation
The standard deviation is a measurement on the average distance the data points are from the central tendency.
\[
s=\sqrt{s^2}
\]

title: Numerical Data
text:
Outliers
These are data points that seem to be highly distant from all other variables.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Histogram
A histogram is a graphical representation of the distribution or frequency of data points in a dataset. It provides a visual way to understand the shape, central tendency, and spread of a dataset by dividing the data into intervals or bins and showing how many data points fall into each bin as a bar.

Box Plot
A box plot, also known as a box-and-whisker plot, is a graphical representation of the distribution and key statistical characteristics of a dataset. It provides a visual summary of the data’s central tendency, spread, and potential outliers.

title: Numerical Data

Transformed Data
When working with skewed data, it may be beneficial to transform the data to identify trends.


\(Y = \ln(X)\)
\(Y = \frac{1}{X}\)
\(Y = \sqrt X\)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Example


Code
library(patchwork)
y <- rlnorm(1000, mean = 0, sd = 2)
ly <- log(y)

p1 <- ggplot(tibble(y), aes(y)) +
  geom_histogram() +
  ggtitle("Skewed Data")
p2 <- ggplot(tibble(y = ly), aes(y)) +
  geom_histogram() +
  ggtitle("Log-Transformed Data")

p1 + p2

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Observations
An observation is the unit which contains information to be obtained.


Also known as experimental unit.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Data
Data is information from a particular experimental unit. There can be more that one piece of information per experimental unit.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Data Structure
The structure of the data can be represented in various forms:

A list of long numbers
Table

title: Data Generating Process
text: Tabular Form

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Measurements
Measurements are the processes where we represent an attribute of an experimental unit as either a number or category.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Quantitative Measurements
Quantitative measurements are data measurements that take a numeric form.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Qualitative Measurements
Qualitative measurements are data measurements that take a certain category.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Value
A value is a description (number or category) of a specific attribute of an experimental unit.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Variable
A variable is the descriptive attribute that we want to obtain from an experimental unit. In terms of a data set, the variable contains all the values of specific attribute in a sample.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Research Question
A research question is designed to create new knowledge of certain phenomenons observed in the world.

This is designed by conducting a research projects that systematically answers the question.


The study design is the procedure in which data is collected to answer the question, while reducing any potential bias while conducting the study.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Study Design
This is the procedure designed to answer a research question.

Entails procedures to collect data that answers a research question.


Dictates how the data will be analyzed.


Determines how the data is quanitified and what is the experimental unit.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Sampling
Sampling is the process of selecting units from a population interest to collect data from.

Image Provided by Simply Psychology.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Sampling
When Sampling you want to maintain these properties:

Representative sample
Large enough sample size

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Sampling Example
We want to answer the question, are people happy?

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Random Sampling
When sampling, we strive for random sampling

Each unit in the population of interest must have an equal probability of being selected for the study.
This ensures a representative population

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Independent Sampling
In addition to random sampling, we strive to make sure each unit is independent from each other.

The probability of UNIT A being sampled will not affect the probability of UNIT B to be sampled.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Sampling Variation

Random samples may vary from the population of interest.
Due to randomness, samples many not look the or biased.
However, this is to be expected as because the sample will not be biased in one way or another.
Samples are then considered unbiased as long as experimental units were collected randomly.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Data
The measurement collected from an experimental unit.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Data Distribution
When thinking about data, we know an attribute is allowed to vary. With this variation, some numbers are more likely to be observed than others.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Forest from the trees

Imamge Provided by Fine Art America.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Sample

When inspecting data:

Do not focus on one individual data point.
See how data points is in relation to other data points.
See what is common
See what is rare

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Data Generation Process (DGP)
The data generation process is understanding how variation from the population is transferred to the data collected.

A population has a mechanism to produce data, understanding this mechanism is essential understanding the data.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
DGP
A populations DGP can be defined with the following characteristics:

The potential outcomes that can be observed when measuring
Each potential outcome will have a probability of being observed

The probability must be between 0 and 1

Sum of all the probabilities of each outcome will add up to 1

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Flipping a Coin
Flipping a coin results in either heads or tail. The probability for heads is 50%

The DGP of flipping a coin is the process of selecting an outcome, given the probability of both options are 50%.

title: Data Generating Process
text: Rolling a die

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Measuring Body Temperature





Image Provided by Thermofisher Scientific.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Inference
How do we use DGP and sampling to understand the world?

We can use a sample to understand the DGP.


We can use the DGP to understand the sample.

title: Data Generating Process
text: Visualizing a DGP

title: Data Generating Process
text: Visualizing DGP

title: Data Generating Process
text: Example

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Statistical Model
\[
Y \sim F(\theta)
\]

\(Y\): A data value generated for DGP
\(F\): A generic mathematical model that describes the DGP
\(\theta\): Parameter controlling the shape and form of the DGP

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Statistical Model
\[
Y = \mu + \varepsilon
\]

\(\mu\): The average value we expect to see
\(\varepsilon \sim F(\cdot)\): Error Term

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Statistical Model
\[
Y = \mu + \varepsilon
\]


\(\mu\): Explained Part

This is what we expect to see if we took an educated guess
The educated guess can incorporate information that is related to \(Y\)


\(\varepsilon\): Unexplained Part

Randomness
Incorporates several types of variation

Measurement Error
Biological Error
Environmental Error

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Standard Normal Distribution


\[
{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}}} e^{-\frac{1}{2}x^2}
\]



Code
data.frame(x = seq(-5,5, length.out = 100), 
           y1 = dt(seq(-5,5, length.out = 100), 1),
           y2 = dt(seq(-5,5, length.out = 100), 10),
           y3 = dt(seq(-5,5, length.out = 100), 30),
           y4 = dt(seq(-5,5, length.out = 100), 100),
           y5 = dnorm((seq(-5,5, length.out = 100)))) |> 
  ggplot() +
  # geom_line(aes(x, y1, color = "1")) +
  # geom_line(aes(x, y2, color = "10")) +
  # geom_line(aes(x, y3, color = "30")) +
  # geom_line(aes(x, y4, color = "100")) +
  geom_line(aes(x, y5)) +
  ylab("y")

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
t Distribution


\[
\frac{\Gamma \left(\frac{v+1}{2}\right)}{\sqrt{\pi v}\Gamma\left(\frac{v}{2}\right)} \left(1 + \frac{x^2}{v}\right)^{-\frac{v+1}{2}}
\]



Code
data.frame(x = seq(-5,5, length.out = 100), 
           y1 = dt(seq(-5,5, length.out = 100), 1),
           y2 = dt(seq(-5,5, length.out = 100), 10),
           y3 = dt(seq(-5,5, length.out = 100), 30),
           y4 = dt(seq(-5,5, length.out = 100), 100),
           y5 = dnorm((seq(-5,5, length.out = 100)))) |> 
  ggplot() +
  geom_line(aes(x, y1, color = "1")) +
  geom_line(aes(x, y2, color = "10")) +
  geom_line(aes(x, y3, color = "30")) +
  geom_line(aes(x, y4, color = "100")) +
  geom_line(aes(x, y5, color = "Normal")) +
  ylab("y")

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Hypothesis


\[H_0: \beta = \theta\]

\[H_0: \beta \ne \theta\]

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Testing \(\beta_j\)
\[
T = \frac{\hat\beta_j-\theta}{\mathrm{se}(\hat\beta_j)} \sim t_{n-p^\prime}
\]

\(n\): sample size
\(p^\prime\): number of \(\beta\)s

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
P-Value



Alternative Hypothesis
p-value




\(\beta>\theta\)
\(P(\hat\beta >T)=p\)


\(\beta<\theta\)
\(P(\hat\beta < T)=p\)


\(\beta\ne\theta\)
\(2\times P(\hat\beta >|T|)=p\)

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Confidence Intervals
\[
\hat \beta_j \pm CV \times se(\hat\beta_j)
\]

\(CV\): Critical Value \(P(X<CV) = 1-\alpha/2\)
\(\alpha\): significance level
\(se\): Standard Error Function

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Conducting HT of \(\beta_j\)


Code
xlm <- lm(Y ~ X, data = DATA)
summary(xlm)

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Example


Code
m1 <- lm(body_mass_g ~ species + flipper_length_mm, penguins)
summary(m1)

#> speciesGentoo       284.52      95.43   2.981 0.003083 **

#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

#> F-statistic: 405.3 on 3 and 329 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Confidence Interval


Code
confint(xlm, level = LEVEL)

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Example


Code
confint(m1, level = 0.90)


#>                           5 %        95 %
#> (Intercept)       -4980.19064 -3046.16714
#> speciesChinstrap   -300.33123  -110.41973
#> speciesGentoo       127.11143   441.93578
#> flipper_length_mm    35.52645    45.68588

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Model inference
We conduct model inference to determine if different models are better at explaining variation. A common example is to compare a linear model (\(\hat Y=\hat\beta_0 + \hat\beta_1 X\)) to the mean of Y (\(\hat \mu_y\)). We determine the significance of the variation explained using an Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) table and F test.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Model Inference
Given 2 models:
\[
\hat Y = \hat\beta_0 + \hat\beta_1 X_1 + \hat\beta_2 X_2 + \cdots + \hat\beta_p X_p
\]
or
\[
\hat Y = \bar y
\]

Is the model with predictors do a better job than using the average?

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text: ANOVA

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
ANOVA Table










Source
DF
SS
MS
F




Model
\(DFR=k-1\)
\(SSR\)
\(MSR=\frac{SSM}{DFR}\)
\(\hat F=\frac{MSR}{MSE}\)


Error
\(DFE=n-k\)
\(SSE\)
\(MSE=\frac{SSE}{DFE}\)



Total
\(TDF=n-1\)
\(TSS=SSR+SSE\)





\[
\hat F \sim F(DFR, DFE)
\]

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Conducting an ANOVA in R


Code
xlm <- lm(Y ~ X, data = DATA)
summary(xlm)

title: Inference with Linear Regression

Example


Code
summary(m1)

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Model Inference
Model inference can be extended to compare models that have different number of predictors.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Model Inference
Given:
\[
M1:\ \hat y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2
\]
\[
M2:\ \hat y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1  
\]
Let \(M1\) be the FULL (larger) model, and let \(M2\) be the RED (Reduced, smaller) model.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Model Inference
He can test the following Hypothesis:

\(H_0\): The error variations between the FULL and RED model are not different.
\(H_1\): The error variations between the FULL and RED model are different.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Test Statistic
\[
\hat F = \frac{[SSE(RED) - SSE(FULL)]/[DFE(RED)-DFE(FULL)]}{MSE(FULL)}
\]
\[
\hat F \sim F[DFE(RED) - DFE(FULL), DFE(FULL)]
\]

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
ANOVA in R


Code
full <- lm(Y  ~  X1 + X2 + X3 + X4)
red <- lm(Y ~ X1 + X2)
anova(red, full)

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Example


Code
m1 <- lm(body_mass_g ~ species + island + flipper_length_mm, penguins)
m2 <- lm(body_mass_g ~ island + flipper_length_mm, penguins)
anova(m2, m1)

#> Model 2: body_mass_g ~ species + island + flipper_length_mm

#> 2    327 45552857  2   2221579 7.9738 0.0004157 ***
#> ---

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Model Assumptions
When we are conducting inference linear regression, we will have to check the following conditions:

Linearity
Independence
Normality
Equal Variances
Multicollinearity (for MLR)

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Linearity
Probably considered the most important assumption, but there must be a linear relationship between both the outcome variable (y) and a set of predictors (\(x_1\), \(x_2\), …).

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Independence
The data points must not influence each other.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Normality
The model errors (also known as residuals) must follow a normal distribution.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Equal Variances
The variability of the data points must be the same for all predictor values.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Residuals
Residuals are the errors between the observed value and the estimated model. Common residuals include

Raw Residual
Standardized Residual
Jackknife (studentized) Residuals

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Influential Measurements
Influential measures are statistics that determine how much a data point affects the model. Common influential measures are

Leverages
Cook’s Distance

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Raw Residuals
\[
\hat r_i = y_i - \hat y_i
\]

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Residual Analysis
A residual analysis is used to test the assumptions of linear regression.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
QQ Plot
A qq (quantile-quantile) plot will plot the estimated quantiles of the residuals against the theoretical quantiles from a normal distribution function. If the points from the qq-plot lie on the \(y=x\) line, it is said that the residuals follow a normal distribution.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Residual vs Fitted Plot
This plot allows you to assess the linearity, constant variance, and identify potential outliers. Create a scatter plot between the fitted values (x-axis) and the raw/standardized residuals (y-axis).

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Variance Inflation Factor
The variance inflation factor is a measurement on how much variables are collinear with each other. A value greater than 10 is a cause for concern and action should be taken.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Residual Analysis in R
Use the resid_df function to obtain the residuals of a model.


Code
rdf <- resid_df(LM_OBJECT)

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Residual vs Fitted Plot


Code
ggplot(RDF, aes(fitted, resid)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0, col = "red")

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
QQ Plot


Code
ggplot(RDF, aes(sample = resid)) + 
  stat_qq() +
  stat_qq_line()

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Example


Code
xlm <- lm(body_mass_g ~   island + species + flipper_length_mm,
          penguins)
dfxlm <- resid_df(xlm)

ggplot(dfxlm, aes(fitted, resid)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0, col = "red")

ggplot(dfxlm, aes(sample = resid)) + 
  stat_qq() +
  stat_qq_line()

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Sampling Distribution
Sampling Distribution is the idea that the statistics that you generate (slopes and intercepts) have their own data generation process.

In other words, the numerical values you obtain from the lm and glm function can be different if we got a different data set.


Some values will be more common than others. Because of this, they have their own data generating process, like the outcome of interest has it’s own data generating process.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Modelling the Data
\[
Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_i + \varepsilon_i
\]

\(Y_i\): Outcome data
\(X_i\): Predictor data
\(\beta_0, \beta_1\): parameters
\(\varepsilon_i\): error term

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Error Term
\[
\varepsilon_i \sim DGP
\]


The error terms forces the outcome variable to be different from the mathematical model.
The numbers being generated are random and cannot be predicted.

title: Sampling Distribution
text: Randomness Effect

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Simulating Unicorns
To better understand the variation in statistics, let’s simulate a data set of unicorn characteristics to visualize and understand the variation.

We will simulate a data set using then unicorns function and only need to specify how many unicorns you want to simulate.

Unicorn Data Variables

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Inference
In the real world, we do not know how the model is generated; therefore, the parameters that are being estimated are unknown.

We use statistics to determine what is our best guess of what the true parameter is.


We can use processes known as inferential procedures to determine which values of the parameter it cannot be. This is known as inference.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Hypothesis Tests
Hypothesis tests are used to test whether claims are valid or not. This is conducted by collecting data, setting the Null and Alternative Hypothesis.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Null Hypothesis \(H_0\)
The null hypothesis is the claim that is initially believed to be true. For the most part, it is always equal to the hypothesized value.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Alternative Hypothesis \(H_a\)
The alternative hypothesis contradicts the null hypothesis.

title: Sampling Distribution
section: Example of Null and Alternative Hypothesis
text:
Example of Null and Alternative Hypothesis
We want to see if \(\mu\) (the true value) is different from \(\mu_0\) (a number we want to test)



Null Hypothesis
Alternative Hypothesis




\(H_0: \mu=\mu_0\)
\(H_a: \mu\ne\mu_0\)


\(H_0: \mu\le\mu_0\)
\(H_a: \mu>\mu_0\)


\(H_0: \mu\ge\mu_0\)
\(H_0: \mu<\mu_0\)

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Hypothesis Test
The idea of hypothesis testing is to generate the sampling distribution of a statistic assuming the null hypothesis is true.

Compute the statistic from your data.


Afterwards, see where your statistic lies in comparison of your null sampling distribution.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Comparison of Null Distribution
If your statistic lies near the mounds, it is believed that your data came from the null distribution.
If your statistic is more in the tail regions, it is believed that your data did not come from your null distribution.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Motivation
The bacteria data set contians information on whether bacteria (y: y or n) is present after utilizing treatments (ap: active or placebo).

We are interesting in determine the proportion of having bacteria present is different for those taking an “active” or “placebo”.

title: Sampling Distribution
text: Crosstabulation

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Comparing Proportions
We are interesting in determining if different groups see different proportions of a binary outcome.
We compute the proportions of observing the binary outcome in Group 1 and Group 2 and see if they are fundamentally different from each other.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
2 by 2 Cross Tabulations



Groups
Outcome 1
Outcome 2


Group 1
\(p_{11}\)
\(p_{21}\)


Group 2
\(p_{12}\)
\(p_{22}\)




We want to compare \(p_{11}\) and \(p_{12}\), to determine if the probability of outcome 1 are the same for both groups.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Test Statistic
We can use both \(p_{11}\) and \(p_{12}\) to determine if there is a fundamental difference.

However, it will be more beneficial to utilize one statistic to contruct the sampling distribution.


\[
T =  p_{11} - p_{12}
\]

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Obtain Proportion in R


Code
props(DATA$GROUP, DATA$OUTCOME, VAL)

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Obtain Difference in R


Code
props(DATA$GROUP, DATA$OUTCOME, VAL, diff = TRUE)

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Bacteria Example


Code
props(bacteria$ap, bacteria$y, "y")


#>     a     p 
#> 0.750 0.875

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Bacteria Example


Code
props(bacteria$ap, bacteria$y, "y", TRUE)


#> [1] 0.125

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Hypothesis Test
Is 12.5% of a difference large enough to indicate that an active drug is effective against the bacteria, or seeing this can be due to random chance.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Hypotheis Test
We will test the following hypothesis:
\[
H_0:\ p_1-p_2 = 0
\]
\[
H_a:\ p_1 - p_2 \neq 0
\]

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Hypothesis Test
In words:
\(H_0\): The variables bacteria presence and active drug treatment are independent of each other.
\(H_a\): The variables bacteria presence and active drug treatment are dependent of each other.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Visualizing


Code
ab <- cat_stats(bacteria$y[bacteria$ap == "a"], pie = TRUE)
abp <- ggplot(ab, aes(fill = Category, values = n)) +
  geom_waffle(make_proportional = TRUE) + 
  ggtitle("Active Treatment") +
  theme_void() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

pbp <- ggplot(pb, aes(fill = Category, values = n)) +
  geom_waffle(make_proportional = TRUE) +
  ggtitle("Placebo") +
  theme_void() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))



abp + pbp + plot_layout(guides = 'collect')

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Randomization Tests
The idea of a randomization test is that each observed outcome variable was dictated by a mathematical model.

Therefore, a randomization is most interested to determine if the mathematical model exist or completely random.


This is equivalent to saying the there is not pattern in the data. IE, independent variables.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Randomization Tests
\(H_0\): The outcome and predictor variables are independent of each other.
\(H_a\): The outcome and predictor variables are dependent of each other.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Randomization Test
The act of randomizing the outcome to a set of predictor variables allow you to construct the sampling of distribution of the null hypothesis.

\(H_0\): The variables bacteria presence and active drug treatment are independent of each other. \(p_{active}-p_{placebo} = 0\)
\(H_a\): The variables bacteria presence and active drug treatment are dependent of each other. \(p_{active}-p_{placebo} \neq 0\)

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Simulating \(H_0\)
We are interested in simulating the distribution for \(p_{active}-p_{placebo}\). We do this by randomly assigning the observed outcomes to the predictor variable. Then, we compute the difference in proportions using the props function. Afterwards, we store the value and repeat the process again.

Lastly, we compare where the data statistic compared to our simulated distribution.

text:
Shuffling Data

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
P-Value
The p-value determines the probability of observing our data statistic, given that the null hypothesis is true.

When the p-value is large, we believe there is a high probability that the null hypothesis is true.


When the p-value is small, we believe that it is unlikely the the null hypothesis is true. We believe that the alternative may be a better model.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
2-Sided P-Value
Due to randomness, there is a possibility of observing the same magnitude of \(p_{active}-p_{placebo}\), but in the opposite direction; therefore, we must look at both sides.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Visually 2-Sided P-Value


Code
ggplot(data.frame(x = sim_stats), aes(x)) + 
  geom_density() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = c(-1,1) *test_stat)

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Computing the p-value
We will count how many simulated \(p_{active}-p_{placebo}\)’s are more extreme than our test statistic and divided by the number of simulations plus one.

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Computing the p-value
\[
p = \frac{m +1}{N + 1}
\]

\(m\): number of more extreme values than our test statistic
\(N\): number of simulations

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Computing the P-Value


Code
(sum(abs(SIM_VECTOR) > abs(TEST_STAT)) + 1) / (N + 1)

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Computing P-value


Code
sum(abs(sim_stats) > abs(test_stat)) / 1001


#> [1] 0.01198801

title: Sampling Distribution
text:
Identify your Variables

What is your predictor variable?
What is your outcome variable?

title: Sampling Distribution
text:

text:
Statistics










With an increasing use of data to make decisions, Statistics has been essential for processing large amounts of data to byte-size information
Statistics is also known as

Data Science
Machine Learning
Artificial Intelligence

So for today, we’re asking: what is Statistics?

title: Statistics
text:
What does Google say?


UC Irvine
Statistics is the science concerned with developing and studying methods for collecting, analyzing, interpreting and presenting empirical data.

Wikipedia
Statistics is a mathematical body of science that pertains to the collection, analysis, interpretation or explanation, and presentation of data, or as a branch of mathematics.

title: Statistics
text:
What does AI say?


ChatGPT
Statistics is a branch of mathematics and a field of study that deals with the collection, analysis, interpretation, presentation, and organization of data.

Google Gemini
Statistics is the science of collecting, analyzing, interpreting, and presenting data.

title: Statistics
text:
What do researchers say?

AnthropologistMicrobiologistSociologistPolitical ScientistEcologistMathematician


Objectively interpreting data to make meaningful inferences about our predictions.


Whatever the statistician says.


Gathering the narratives of individuals, groups, or society and telling a story about their past, present, or future. The numbers paint a picture worth many words.


Using numbers to try to explain behaviors and/or patterns in our world.


Statistics is the way to make sense of the natural world by taking data we collect to identify patterns between variables, and applying statistical theory to make sure we are taking the right approach to data collection and analysis. Also, assess patterns to see if they are reproducible and provide a logical explanation that makes biological sense.


Statistics is the study of data, patterns, and trends.

title: Statistics
text:
What is it?


Math






Science

title: Statistics
text:
What does a Statistician say?
It is the study of variation and randomness!

Using mathematics, we model randomness to characterizes commonality and variation!


Using science, we systematically refine models to better fit randomness in data!


Using art, when it all eventually fails!

title: Statistics
section: What if we cannot construct the distribution?!?!
text:
What if we cannot construct the distribution?!?!











We bring out the Monte Carlo methods!

title: Statistics
text:
Monte Carlo Methods

Monte Carlo Methods are used to construct a distribution function of an obscure test statistic
We simulate a large number of data sets based on the null hypothesis
We construct a test statistic for each fake data set and the real one
We count how many data sets produce a test statistic that is more extreme than the real test statistic
\(p=\#\ of\ extreme\ data\ sets\ /\ all\ data\ sets\)

There are two train of thoughts on how to interpret estimates and probability.


One approach is the Frequentist approach.


The other approach is the Bayesian approach.


Both sides hate each other.

Frequentists
A frequentist, in the context of statistics, is an individual who adheres to the frequentist interpretation of probability and statistical inference.

Meaning probability is obtained by the repetition of multiple experiments.

Bayesians
A Bayesians, in the context of statistics, is an individual who adheres to the Bayesian interpretation of probability and statistical inference.

Probability is obtained by likelihood of an event to occur, given data and prior knowledge.

Use of Generative AI
The use of generative artificial intelligence (AI) will be prohibited in class. This includes, but not limited to, ChatGPT, Meta AI, and Google Gemini.

title: Welcome!
text:
Educational Mislearning
The purpose of this class, and college, is for you to learn about critical thinking skills and perseverance. Using AI will only teach you how to get an answer, which may or may not be correct.

You will not develop the skills needed to problem solve a challenge. Additionally, developing grit is essential to become successful in college and life. There is no easy way out and AI is an illusion to your success in life.


To learn something, it requires hours of work! If not years!

title: Welcome!
section: Stolen WorkMonday have their work to be used this way.
text:
Stolen WorkMonday have their work to be used this way.

Additionally, all these individuals are not receiving any royalties for the work to be used in creating generative AI models.


Inside Higher Ed and The New Yorker highlight individual’s concern of their work being used to train AI models.

title: Welcome!
text:
Privacy Concerns
The use of generative AI raises concerns of what data is being harvested from us, possibly without informed consent.

When you used any large language models, you do not know what information is being harvested from you.


Do you want to upload your thoughts and ideas to a company that can monetize, and possibly exploit.


Does your Professors consent with you uploading their assignments to large language models.


Stanford provided a report highlighting the risks of our personal data use in large language models.

title: Welcome!
text:
Math 201 Consent

Dr. Isaac Quintanilla Salinas consents in you sharing course material to your friends and family for learning purposes. Use the material to educate and uplift your community.


Dr. Isaac Quintanilla Salinas does not consent in you sharing course material to companies/corporations. Additionally, I do not consent in the use of course material for academic dishonesty. Exceptions are allowed for DASS-approved services.

title: Welcome!
text:
Environmental Impact
In order to run these large language models, companies need to use a large amounts of energy. This is because large servers are needed to both train and execute a model.

The LA Times reports the potential impact that running AI models in California.


Additionally, Time reports that a ChatGPT query uses ten times more energy than a Google search query, and global AI demands can consume of 1 trillion gallons of water by 2027.


There are also environmental justice questions about where these data centers are constructed.

title: Welcome!
text:
Worker Exploitation
The Washington Post and Time (Article 1 and Article 2) reported that AI companies utilize “digital sweatshops” to classify data points for model training.

There is a human cost from the Global South, both financially and mentally, to develop the AI models for users in the United States and Europe.


We must be conscious consumers and demand more from these companies to provide safe working conditions and livable wages.

title: Welcome!
section: How will the Profesor enforce the policy?

How will the Profesor enforce the policy?

I am not! Unless it is extremely obvious, it is extremely difficult to identify AI use.


Cell has an article indicating that the use of GPT detectors harm non-native English speakers.

title: Welcome!
text:
Is Using AI Bad?

NO


What we should do is demand companies to develop these tools in an ethical manner!

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Melanoma
Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that causes the cells that produce melanin to grow out of control. What makes Melanoma so dangerous is that it can metastasize to other parts of the body.

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Outcome of Interest
We are interested in learning how do different factors affect and individual’s chances of survival. Therefore, we are measuring patients and if they lived or died during a study period.

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Data
We will be using the Melanoma data set with the following variables: dead (died by Melanoma, 1=yes, 0= no), sex (1 = male, 0 = female), age (in years), thickness (tumour thickness in mm), ulcer (1 = presence, 0 absent).

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Plot


Code
Melanoma |> 
  ggplot(aes(thickness, dead)) +
  geom_point()

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Construct Model
\[
\left(\begin{array}{c}
Dead \\
Alive
\end{array}\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1X
\]

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Let …
\[
Y = \left\{\begin{array}{cc}
1 & Dead \\
0 & Alive
\end{array}\right.
\]

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Construct a Model
\[
P\left(Y = 1\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1X
\]

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Construct a Model
\[
P\left(Y = 1\right) = \frac{e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}{1 + e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}
\]

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Construct a Model
\[
\frac{P(Y = 1)}{P(Y = 0)} = e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}
\]
where \(\frac{P(Y = 1)}{P(Y = 0)}\) are considered the odds of observing \(Y = 1\).

title: Poisson Regression
text:
The Logistic Model
\[
\log\left\{\frac{P(Y = 1)}{P(Y = 0)}\right\} = \beta_0 + \beta_1X
\]

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Logistic Regression
Logistic Regression is used to model the association between a set of predictors and a binary outcome variable.

This is similar Linear Regression which models the association between a set of predictors and a numerical outcome variable.

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Logistic Regression
Logistic Regression uses the logistic model to formulate the relationship between the predictors and the outcome.

More specifically, for an outcome of Y:
\[
Y = \left\{\begin{array}{cc}
1 & \text{Category 1} \\
0 & \text{Category 2}
\end{array}\right.
\]
The Predictors variable will model the probability of observing category 1 (\(P(Y=1)\))

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Logistic Model
\[
\log\left\{\frac{P(Y = 1)}{P(Y = 0)}\right\} = \beta_0 + \beta_1X
\]

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Regression Coefficients \(\beta\)
The regression coefficients quantify how a specific predictor changes the odds of observing the first category of the outcome (\(Y = 1\))

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Estimating \(\beta\)
To obtain the numerical value for \(\beta\), denoted as \(\hat \beta\), we will be finding the values of \(\hat \beta\) that maximizes the likelihood function:
\[
L(\boldsymbol \beta) = \prod_{i=1}^n \left(\frac{e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}{1 + e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}\right)^{Y_i}\left(\frac{1}{1 + e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}\right)^{1-Y_i}
\]
The likelihood function can be thought as the probability of observing the entire data set. Therefore, we want to choose the values the \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) that will result in the highest probability of observing the data.

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Estimated Parameters
The values you obtain (\(\hat \beta\)) tell you the relationship between the a predictor variable and the log odds of observing the first category of the outcome \(Y=1\).

Exponentiating the estimate (\(e^{\hat \beta}\)) will give you the relationship between a predictor variable and the odds of observing the first category of the outcome \(Y=1\).

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Interpreting \(\hat \beta\)
For a continuous predictor variable:
As X increases by 1 unit, the odds of observing the first category (\(Y = 1\)) increases by a factor of \(e^{\hat\beta}\).
For a categorical predictor variable (first dummy variable):
The odds of observing the first category (\(Y = 1\)) in the indicated category (\(D=1\)) is \(e^{\hat\beta}\) times higher/lower compared to the reference category (\(D=0\)).

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Logistic Regression in R


Code
glm(Y ~ X1 + X2 + ... + Xp,
    data = DATA,
    family = binomial())

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Example
Modelling dead by sex, age, thickness, and ulcer:


Code
glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())


#> 
#> Call:  glm(formula = dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer, family = binomial(), 
#>     data = Melanoma)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#> (Intercept)          sex          age    thickness        ulcer  
#>    -2.39860      0.40767      0.00402      0.11253      1.31314  
#> 
#> Degrees of Freedom: 204 Total (i.e. Null);  200 Residual
#> Null Deviance:       242.4 
#> Residual Deviance: 210.3     AIC: 220.3


\[
\log(odds) = -2.40 + 0.41 M + 0.004 age + 0.11 thick + 1.31ulc
\]

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Interpretation
\[
\log(odds) = -2.40 + 0.41 M + 0.004 age + 0.11 thick + 1.31ulc
\]

The odds of experiencing death in males is 1.5 times larger than the odds for females, adjusting for age, tumor thickness and the presence of an ulcer.


As age increases by 1 year, the odds of experiencing death increases by a factor of 1.004, adjusting for sex, tumor thickness and presence of an ulcer.

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Working with probabilities
As you can see, working with odds may be unintuitive for the average person. It will be better to predict the probability and display those results to individuals.

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Predicting Probability
\[
\hat P\left(Y = 1\right) = \frac{e^{\hat\beta_0 + \hat\beta_1X_1 + \cdots  + \hat \beta_pX_p}}{1 + e^{\hat\beta_0 + \hat\beta_1X_1 + \cdots  + \hat \beta_pX_p}}
\]

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Prediction in R


Code
xglm <- glm(Y ~ X1 + X2 + ... + Xp,
            data = DATA,
            family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(X1 = VAL,  X2 = VAL, ..., Xp = VAL)
predict(xglm,
        predict_df,
        type = "response")

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Example 1
Predict the probability of observing death for a patient who is male, 75 years old, an tumor thickness of 2.9, and with ulcer presence.


Code
xglm <- glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(sex = 1, age = 75, thickness = 2.9, ulcer = 1)
predict(xglm, predict_df, type = "response")


#>         1 
#> 0.4875223

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Example 1
Predict the probability of observing death for a patient who is male, 75 years old, an tumor thickness of 2.9, and without ulcer presence.


Code
xglm <- glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(sex = 1, age = 75, thickness = 2.9, ulcer = 0)
predict(xglm, predict_df, type = "response")


#>         1 
#> 0.2037438

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Example 1




Ulcer Present
Ulcer not Present




Probabiltiy
48.7%
20.3%



For a patient who is 75 years old, male, and a tumor thickness of 2.9, when an ulcer is present, the probability a patient dies increases to 48% compared to a patient who does not have an ulcer with a probability of 20%.

title: Poisson Regression
text:
Example 2
Predict the probability of observing death for a patient who is female, 75 years old, an tumor thickness of 2.9, and with ulcer presence.


Code
xglm <- glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(sex = 0, age = 75, thickness = 2.9, ulcer = 1)
predict(xglm, predict_df, type = "response")


#>         1 
#> 0.3875575

title: Inference
text:
Real or Random

Does smoking have a protective effect on having a premature infant?


Does the number of hospital visits have a protective effect?


What is real and what is random?

title: Inference
text:
Hypothesis Tests
Hypothesis tests are used to test whether claims are valid or not. This is conducted by collecting data, setting the Null and Alternative Hypothesis.

title: Inference
text:
Null Hypothesis \(H_0\)
The null hypothesis is the claim that is initially believed to be true. For the most part, it is always equal to the hypothesized value.

title: Inference
text:
Alternative Hypothesis \(H_a\)
The alternative hypothesis contradicts the null hypothesis.

title: Inference
section: Example of Null and Alternative Hypothesis
text:
Example of Null and Alternative Hypothesis
We want to see if \(\beta\) is different from \(\beta^*\)



Null Hypothesis
Alternative Hypothesis




\(H_0: \beta=\beta^*\)
\(H_a: \beta\ne\beta^*\)


\(H_0: \beta\le\beta^*\)
\(H_a: \beta>\beta^*\)


\(H_0: \beta\ge\beta^*\)
\(H_0: \beta<\beta^*\)

title: Inference
text:
One-Side vs Two-Side Hypothesis Tests
Notice how there are 3 types of null and alternative hypothesis, The first type of hypothesis (\(H_a:\beta\ne\beta^*\)) is considered a 2-sided hypothesis because the rejection region is located in 2 regions. The remaining two hypotheses are considered 1-sided because the rejection region is located on one side of the distribution.



Null Hypothesis
Alternative Hypothesis
Side




\(H_0: \beta=\beta^*\)
\(H_a: \beta\ne\beta^*\)
2-Sided


\(H_0: \beta\le\beta^*\)
\(H_a: \beta>\beta^*\)
1-Sided


\(H_0: \beta\ge\beta^*\)
\(H_0: \beta<\beta^*\)
1-Sided

title: Inference
text:
Decision Making
Hypothesis Testing will force you to make a decision: Reject \(H_0\) OR Fail to Reject \(H_0\)

Reject \(H_0\): The effect seen is not due to random chance, there is a process making contributing to the effect.


Fail to Reject \(H_0\): The effect seen is due to random chance. Random sampling is the reason why an effect is displayed, not an underlying process.

title: Inference
text:
Decision Making: P-Value
The p-value approach is one of the most common methods to report significant results. It is easier to interpret the p-value because it provides the probability of observing our test statistics, or something more extreme, given that the null hypothesis is true.

If \(p < \alpha\), then you reject \(H_0\); otherwise, you will fail to reject \(H_0\).

title: Inference
text:
Decision Making: Confidence Interval Approach
The confidence interval approach can evaluate a hypothesis test where the alternative hypothesis is \(\beta\ne\beta^*\). The bootstrapping approach will result in a lower and upper bound denoted as: \((LB, UB)\).

If \(\beta^*\) is in \((LB, UB)\), then you fail to reject \(H_0\). If \(\beta^*\) is not in \((LB,UB)\), then you reject \(H_0\).

title: Inference
text:
Significance Level \(\alpha\)
The significance level \(\alpha\) is the probability you will reject the null hypothesis given that it was true.

In other words, \(\alpha\) is the error rate that a research controls.


Typically, we want this error rate to be small (\(\alpha = 0.05\)).

title: Inference
text:
Hypothesis Test Process


Set up the Null and Alternative Hypothesis.

\(H_0: \beta = 0\) and \(H_a: \beta \ne 0\)

Compute p-value or confidence interval
Make a decision
Interpret the results

text:
Hypothesis


\[H_0: \beta = \theta\]

\[H_0: \beta \ne \theta\]

title: Inference with Logistic and Poisson Regression
text:
Testing \(\beta_j\)
\[
\frac{\hat\beta_j - \theta}{\mathrm{se}(\hat\beta_j)} \sim N(0,1)
\]

title: Inference with Logistic and Poisson Regression
text:
Confidence Intervals
\[
PE \pm CV \times SE
\]

PE: Point Estimate
CV: Critical Value \(P(X<CV) = 1-\alpha/2\)
\(\alpha\): significance level
SE: Standard Error

title: Inference with Logistic and Poisson Regression
text:
Model inference
We conduct model inference to determine if different models are better at explaining variation. A common example is to compare a linear model (\(g(\hat Y)=\hat\beta_0 + \hat\beta_1 X\)) to the mean of Y (\(\hat \mu_y\)). We determine the significance of the variation explained using an Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) table and F test.

title: Inference with Logistic and Poisson Regression
text:
Model Inference
Given 2 models:
\[
g(\hat Y) = \hat\beta_0 + \hat\beta_1 X_1 + \hat\beta_2 X_2 + \cdots + \hat\beta_p X_p
\]
or
\[
g(\hat Y) = \bar y
\]

Is the model with predictors do a better job than using the average?

title: Inference with Logistic and Poisson Regression
text:
Likelihood Ratio Test
The Likelihood Ratio Test is a test to determine whether the likelihood of observing the outcome is significantly bigger in a larger, more complicated model, than a simpler model.
It conducts a hypothesis tests to see if models are significantly different from each other.

title: Inference with Logistic and Poisson Regression
text:
Conducting an LRT in R


Code
xlm <- glm(Y ~ X, data = DATA, family = binomial)
xlm0 <- glm(Y ~ 1, data = DATA, family = binomial)
anova(xlm0, xlm, test = "LRT")

title: Inference with Logistic and Poisson Regression
text:
Example


Code
m0 <- update(m1, formula. = ~ 1)
anova(m0, m1, test = "LRT")


#> Analysis of Deviance Table
#> 
#> Model 1: death ~ 1
#> Model 2: death ~ recur + number + size
#>   Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi)    
#> 1       293     189.38                         
#> 2       290     166.43  3   22.953 4.13e-05 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

title: Inference with Logistic and Poisson Regression
text:
Model Inference
Model inference can be extended to compare models that have different number of predictors.

title: Inference with Logistic and Poisson Regression
text:
Model Inference
Given:
\[
M1:\ g(\hat y) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2
\]
\[
M2:\ g(\hat y) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1  
\]
Let \(M1\) be the FULL (larger) model, and let \(M2\) be the RED (Reduced, smaller) model.

title: Inference with Logistic and Poisson Regression
text:
Model Inference
He can test the following Hypothesis:

\(H_0\): The error variations between the FULL and RED model are not different.
\(H_1\): The error variations between the FULL and RED model are different.

title: Inference with Logistic and Poisson Regression
text:
Likelihood Ratio Test in R


Code
full <- glm(Y  ~  X1 + X2 + X3 + X4, DATA, family = binomial())
red <- glm(Y ~ X1 + X2, DATA, family = binomial())
anova(red, full, test = "LRT")

Background
In October 2023, James Hoffman and Cometeer held the “Great American Coffee Taste Test” on YouTube, asking viewers to fill out a survey and coffee ordered from Cometeer.

Information on the data sets variables (columns) can be found here.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Categorical Data
Categorical data are data recordings that represented a category.

Data may be recorded as a “character” or “string” data.


Data may be recorded as a whole number, with an attached code book indicating the categories each number belongs to.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Examples of Categorical Data


Are you a student?
What city do you live in?
What is your major?

title: Categorical Data
text:
Likert Scale
Likert scales are the rating systems you may have answered in surveys.


Strongly Disagree
Disagree
Neutral
Agree
Strongly Agree

title: Categorical Data
text:
Likert Scales
Likert scales may be treated as numerical data if the jumps between scales are equal.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Summarizing Categorical Data
Once we have the data, how do we summarize it to other people.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Continguency Tables
Continguency tables display how often a category is seen in the data.

There are two types of statistics that are reported in a table, the frequency and proportion.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Frequencey
Frequency represents the count of observing a specific category in your sample.


#>  [1] "Less than 1" "Less than 1" "3"           "2"           "1"           "Less than 1" "3"           "1"           "3"           "2"

title: Categorical Data
text:
Proportions (relative frequencey)
Proportions represent the percentage that the category represents the sample.

This allows you to generalize your sample to the population, regardless of sample size.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Continguency Tables in R
The variable caffeine indicates how much caffeine a participant prefers.

cat_stats(coffee$caffeine)

title: Categorical Data
text:
Data
The variable taste indicates if the participants like the taste of coffee.

cat_stats(coffee$taste)

title: Categorical Data
text:
Cross-Tabulation
Cross-tabulations, also known as contingency tables, are statistical tools used to analyze the relationship between two or more categorical variables by displaying their frequency distribution in a table format. Each cell in the table represents the count or frequency of observations that fall into a particular combination of categories for the variables.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Key Features of Cross-Tabulations

Rows and Columns:

Rows represent the categories of one variable.
Columns represent the categories of another variable.

Cells:

Each cell displays the frequency or count of data points that belong to the intersection of a row and column category.

Margins:

Row and column totals provide summaries for each variable.
The grand total shows the overall sample size.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Types of Proportions in Cross-Tabulations

Row Proportions: Show the percentage of each row total represented by a cell.
Column Proportions: Show the percentage of each column total represented by a cell.
Table Proportions: Show the percentage of the overall total represented by a cell.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Table Proportions
Table proportions in cross-tabulations refer to the relative frequency or percentage of counts within the entire table, calculated by dividing each cell’s count by the total sum of all counts in the table. These proportions allow you to examine the contribution of each cell to the overall data set.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Table Proportions

cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, coffee$taste, prop = "table")

title: Categorical Data
text:
Row Proportions
Row proportions refer to the relative frequency or percentage of counts within each row of a contingency table. In a cross-tabulation, row proportions allow you to compare how the distribution of one variable varies within each category of another variable, within a row.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Row Proportions

cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, coffee$taste, prop = "row")

title: Categorical Data
text:
Column Proportions
Column proportions refer to the relative frequency or percentage of counts within each column of a contingency table. These proportions allow you to compare how the distribution of one variable varies across different categories of another variable, within a column.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Column Proportions

cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, coffee$taste, prop = "col")

text:
Stacked Bar Plot in R

ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR1, y = after_stat(count), fill = VAR2)) +
  geom_bar()

text:

  geom_bar()

ggplot(coffee, aes(y = caffeine, x = after_stat(count), fill = taste)) +

title: Categorical Data
text:
Pie Charts
A pie chart is a circular statistical graphic divided into slices, where each slice represents a proportion or percentage of the whole. The size of each slice is proportional to the relative frequency or magnitude of the category it represents.

title: Categorical Data
text: Pie Charts

title: Categorical Data
text:
Key Features of Pie Charts

Circular Format:

The chart is shaped like a circle, symbolizing a whole (100% or 1).

Slices:

Each slice corresponds to a category and its size represents the contribution of that category to the total.

Labels:

Slices are often labeled with the category name and the percentage or value they represent.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Pie Chart in R

df_pie <- cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, tbl_df = TRUE)$table
ggplot(df_pie, aes(cat = Category, val = n, fill = Category)) +
  geom_pie()

title: Categorical Data
text:
Pie Chart in R

coffee_pie <- cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, tbl_df = TRUE)$table
ggplot(coffee_pie, aes(cat = Category, val = n, fill = Category)) +
  geom_pie()

title: Categorical Data
text:
Mosaic Plots
A mosaic plot is a graphical representation of two categorical variables. It uses rectangles to visualize the proportions of data categories while simultaneously showing the relationships between multiple variables. The size of each rectangle corresponds to the relative frequency or proportion of the data in a particular category combination.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Key Features of Mosaic Plots

Rectangular Tiles:

The plot is divided into rectangles, with each tile representing a unique combination of categories.

Proportional Areas:

The area of each rectangle is proportional to the frequency or proportion of the data it represents.

Hierarchical Arrangement:

Variables are arranged hierarchically along the axes, with the tiles subdivided to represent relationships between variables.

Color Coding (Optional):

Different colors can be used to highlight specific patterns, emphasize groups, or indicate significance.

title: Categorical Data
text: Mosiac Plots

title: Categorical Data
text:
Mosiac Plots in R

ggplot(DATA) +Waffle Charts is similar to the pie charts where you can visualize the proportions.

#| echo: true
#| eval: true
ggplot(coffee) +
  geom_mosaic(aes(x = product(caffeine, taste), fill = taste))

title: Categorical Data
text:
Waffle Charts
A waffle chart is a grid-based visualization used to display proportions or percentages in a dataset. It represents parts of a whole by dividing a grid into small squares, where each square corresponds to a specific percentage or unit of the total.

title: Categorical Data
text:
Key Features of Waffle Charts

Grid Structure:

Composed of small squares arranged in rows and columns, typically forming a 10x10 grid (100 squares for 100%).

Proportional Representation:

Each square represents an equal portion of the total, such as 1% in a 10x10 grid.

Color Coding:

Different colors are used to represent different categories or groups.

title: Categorical Data
text: Waffle Charts

title: Categorical Data
text:
Waffle Charts in R

df_pie <- cat_stats(coffee$caffeine, tbl_df = TRUE)$table
ggplot(df_pie, aes(cat = Category, values = n)) +
  geom_waffle(make_proportional = TRUE)
